Fig. 1 (a) Methanol conversion plotted vs. reaction temperature, (b) hydrogen and carbon monoxide selectivity plotted vs. reaction temperature during partial oxidation for catalysts (●) 7Cu/3Zn, (■) 7Cu/3Zn–Pd, (○) 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr, and (▴) 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd. Fig. 2 X-ray intensity vs. diffraction angle for calcined catalysts (a) 7Cu/3Zn–Pd, (b) 7Cu/3Zn, (c) 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr, and (d) 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd catalysts. Peaks belonging to oxide phases identified as (●) CuO, and (▴) ZnO. Fig. 3 Hydrogen TPR profiles as hydrogen uptake vs. temperature for calcined catalysts (a) 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd, (b) 7Cu/3Zn–Pd, (c) 7Cu/3Zr/1Zr, and (d) 7Cu/3Zn. Fig. 4 Cu XANES plotted as the normalized X-ray absorption vs. incident X-ray energy under reaction conditions for catalysts (a) Cu/Zn and (b) Cu/Zn–Pd at various temperatures labeled as (—) 25°C, (⋯) 150°C, (––) 200°C, (· –) 250°C. Fig. 5 Pd EXAFS region plotted as the magnitude of the FT[k 2*χ(k)] vs. bond distance at 25°C for: (thin —) Pd0 reference foil, (thick —) 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd under reduced and reaction conditions, (––) D-7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd deactivated in air, and (⋯) D-7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd fresh calcined in air. Fig. 6 Pd EXAFS region plotted as the magnitude of the FT[k 2*χ(k)] vs. bond distance at 25°C in hydrogen after reduction for: (thin —) Pd0 supported on Al2O3, (– ·) Al-3, (––) Al-5, and (⋯) Zn−3. Fig. 7 Plot of Pd–M alloy coordination number vs. prepared Cu/Pd molar ratio for (▴) ZnO supported and (■) Al2O3 supported catalysts. Outliers (▵) ZnO and (□) Al2O3 are not included in the trend line fitting. Fig. 8 Plot of methanol conversion, hydrogen, carbon dioxide, and carbon monoxide selectivity vs. time during a 100-h stability test for catalyst 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd under reaction conditions at 200°C. Fig. 9 Plot of X-ray intensity vs. diffraction angle for spent catalyst D-7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd used in the 100-h stability test. Peaks belonging to detected phases are labeled as (●) Cu0, (▴) ZnO, (■) tetragonal ZrO2 and (□) monoclinic ZrO2. Copper and zinc oxide based catalysts prepared by coprecipitation were promoted with palladium and ZrO2, and their activity and selectivity for methanol oxidative reforming was measured and characterized by N2O decomposition, X-ray absorption spectroscopy, BET, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction, and temperature programmed reduction. Addition of ZrO2 increased copper dispersion and surface area, with little effect on activity, while palladium promotion significantly enhanced activity with little change of the catalytic structure. A catalyst promoted with both ZrO2 and palladium yielded hydrogen below 150°C. EXAFS results under reaction conditions showed that the oxidation state of copper was influenced by palladium in the catalyst bulk. A palladium promoted catalyst contained 90% Cu0, while the copper in an unpromoted catalyst was 100% Cu1+ at the same temperature. Palladium preferentially forms an unstable alloy with copper instead of zinc during reduction, which persists during reaction regardless of copper oxidation state. A 100-h time on stream activity measurement showed growth in copper crystallites and change in copper oxidation state resulting in decreasing activity and selectivity. A kinetic model of the reaction pathway showed that palladium and ZrO2 promoters lower the activation energy of methanol combustion and steam reforming reactions. Graphical abstract Copper and zinc based catalysts were promoted with palladium and zirconium. The zirconium promoter increased copper dispersion, while the palladium promoter enhanced copper reducibility under reaction conditions. Upon reduction, palladium was found to form alloys with copper, which was reversible on exposure to air. Deactivated catalyst had a greater fraction of copper as Cu1+ under reaction conditions. Keywords Methanol Partial oxidation Copper Palladium alloy X-ray absorption spectroscopy 1 Introduction Hydrogen has potential for use as a localized energy source to replace batteries inside electronic devices in small fuel cells. Proton-exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cells using hydrogen as fuel are efficient, quiet, and have near zero harmful emissions [1,2]. Hydrogen can be extracted from sources including natural gas, water, biomass, or other more complex hydrocarbons [3–5]. Methanol is an abundant commodity chemical that can be stored as a liquid at ambient temperatures and shows promise as a localized hydrogen source. Several different reaction pathways exist for producing hydrogen from methanol including methanol decomposition (MD), steam reforming (SRM), partial oxidation (POM), and combined steam and oxidative reforming (CMR). Operation of PEM fuel cells using precious metal catalysts require a hydrogen feed containing less than 50ppm CO to avoid electrode poisoning [6]. Steam reforming has the highest hydrogen to carbon ratio. However, this reaction is highly endothermic and is not suitable for applications where a heat source is unavailable or bursts of energy may be needed. Partial oxidation is exothermic, with a higher reaction rate than steam reforming and reduced tendency to form CO [7]. Copper based catalysts have been extensively used and studied for methanol synthesis, water gas shift (WGS), SRM, POM, and CMR reactions [8–12]. Traditional copper methanol synthesis catalysts are prepared with ZnO and Al2O3. Palladium is the other most widely studied active component for methanol reforming. When prepared on certain oxide supports, palladium is an effective decomposition catalyst, selectively forming H2 and CO [13–16]. However, palladium paired with ZnO has high selectivity for CO2 in the SRM reaction. The change in selectivity to CO2 has been attributed to the formation of Pd–Zn alloys on reduction in hydrogen at moderate temperatures [17–19]. A number of papers have demonstrated positive effects from promotion of copper catalysts with ZrO2. A CuO/ZrO2 catalyst used in steam reforming was found to have higher activity than a commercial CuO/ZnO/Al2O3 while still maintaining deactivation resistance [20]. Zirconia has also been shown to promote to Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 efficiently producing H2 with low CO levels [12,21,22]. Another set of studies by Fisher and Bell focused on the mechanism of methanol synthesis and decomposition proposed a synergy between copper and ZrO2 where reaction intermediates were found on the ZrO2 [23–25]. In a previous works we reported activity results of the oxidative reforming of methanol in multicomponent catalysts [26,27]. Using a high throughput technique for catalyst activity evaluation we determined that a catalyst containing molar ratios of 7CuO/3ZnO/1ZrO2 with 1% Pd prepared by coprecipitation achieved 92% H2 selectivity at 100% methanol conversion with 1400ppm of carbon monoxide produced. This work focuses on studying by kinetic and spectroscopic methods the effects of the various catalytic components to understand their effect in activity in terms of structure, alloy and oxidation states under operando conditions, stability, and the reaction mechanism. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Catalysts were prepared via the constant pH coprecipitation method using soluble metal precursors. In this case, nitrates of Cu, Zn, Zr, and Pd were precipitated with stoichiometric amounts of Na2CO3. The precipitation was monitored and controlled to a pH of 7 by small adjustments of precipitating agent flow rate. The resulting slurry was aged overnight under continued heating and stirring. The precipitate was filtered and thoroughly washed to minimize residual sodium ions, followed by drying at 100°C overnight. Finally, the catalyst was ground into a fine powder using a mortar and calcined in air at 500°C for 2h. Compositions of the four catalysts selected for study in this work are listed in Table 1 . They consist of an unpromoted copper and zinc catalyst (7Cu/3Zn), singly promoted copper/zinc with zirconium or palladium (7Cu/3Zn/1Zr and 7Cu/3Zn–Pd), and a doubly promoted catalyst with copper, zinc, zirconium, and palladium (7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd). Catalysts are referred to according to their composition in molar ratio, with palladium as 1wt.% based on total oxide mass. Nominal catalyst composition and inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) measured composition are listed in Table 1, with good agreement between target and observed compositions. Additionally, two series of supported catalysts, on ZnO and Al2O3, were prepared to study alloy formation in the Cu/Zn/Pd system. The ZnO support was made by precipitating Zn(NO3)2 as described above. The γ-Al2O3 support was obtained commercially (Harshaw, Al-4100). Metals were loaded using incipient wetness impregnation of Cu, Pd, and Zn metal nitrates. Exact compositions can be found in Tables 6 and 7, where alumina-supported series catalysts are numbered Al-i and ZnO supported are numbered Zn-i where i =1–6. After drying overnight at 100°C the catalysts were calcined in air at 400°C. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Multiple characterization techniques were used to determine the composition, oxidation state of the bulk as well as the surface. Unfortunately, most surface sensitive techniques, cannot be used under operando conditions and most methods that can be used under reaction conditions are not surface sensitive. Therefore the results are specific to the conditions required by the techniques used and their interpretation must be weighted against these constraints. BET total surface area: A one-point N2 adsorption method was used to measure BET area in a Monosorb unit (Quantachrom Corp.) that utilizes a dynamic technique with a thermal conductivity (TC) cell for measuring desorption of nitrogen. BET measurements of reduced catalysts were made after first flowing hydrogen at 300°C for 1h to reduce the catalysts, then outgasing with a He/N2 mixture at 250°C for 30min without exposure to the atmosphere. The reduced area was corrected by the amount of mass lost due to the reduction of copper from CuO to Cu0. X-ray diffraction: A Scintag Inc. X-ray diffractometer sourced 30kV, 30mA, Cu Kα radiation at a wavelength of 0.15406nm with a solid-state detector measuring X-ray intensity as a function of scattering angle 2θ was used for powder X-ray diffraction analysis in air. Because the reduced samples were pyrophoric, the reduced catalysts could not be analyzed by XRD and only the fresh calcined catalysts and a spent catalyst after 100-h time on stream were analyzed. X-ray photolectron spectroscopy (XPS): A Kratos XSAM-800 instrument with an Al Kα X-ray source operating at 1486.6eV and a 90° takeoff angle was used to obtain XPS results. Freshly ground powder catalyst samples were adhered to brass mounts with double-sided carbon tape prior to loading into the analysis chamber. A small amount of silica well mixed with the catalyst powders served as an inert internal standard. Samples were left to degas overnight while the vacuum system maintained a pressure less than 1×10−8 Torr. Instrumental control and data collection were done using the Vision2 software package. Catalysts were calcined or reduced ex situ prior to being analyzed by XPS. Samples were reduced in flowing hydrogen at 300°C for 1h. To avoid oxidation of the reduced catalyst powders, a sealed glove box purged with oxygen free argon was used to prepare and load samples. Cu surface area: Mean and specific copper surface areas were measured by a well-known decomposition method [28–31] where N2O reacts with surface Cu0 with the following stoichiometry: (1) 2Cu+N2O→Cu2O+N2 While several methods have been developed based on the above reaction [32], N2O experiments in this paper utilized a pulse method. At least 100mg of fresh catalyst sieved to 0.6–1mm was loaded into a quartz reactor supported on quartz wool. The sample was reduced by flowing 5% H2 in Ar heating to temperature of 300°C. Carrier gas was then switched to pure N2 while the temperature was maintained for 10min to clean any residual hydrogen or water. Following reduction, the reactor was quickly cooled to 60°C, this temperature was maintained constant for the duration of the experiment. Pulses of 1cm3 5% N2O in N2 were injected into a carrier stream of N2 flowing at 50cm3 min−1 until uptake of N2O reached zero. Conversion of N2O was monitored using a gold plated tungsten thermal conductivity detector (TCD) with a current of 90mA. Dispersion, mean, and specific surface areas were calculated assuming a Cu surface atomic density of 1.47×1019 atomsm−2. Temperature programmed reduction (TPR): To study the effect of promoters on the reducibility of copper the uptake of hydrogen was measured by a TPR method. 75.0mg of fresh sieved catalyst was loaded into a quartz reactor supported on quartz wool. A type K thermocouple inserted into the middle of the catalytic bed was used to measure temperature and control heating rate. The experiments were conducted using 5% H2 in Ar flowing at 100cm3 min−1 beginning at room temperature with a linear heating rate of 5°Cmin−1 up to 350°C which ensured complete copper reduction. Water was prevented from entering the detector by passing the reactor effluent through a stainless steel coil immersed in a bath of dry ice, acetone, and 2-propanol. Elemental analysis: Content of copper, zinc, zirconium, and palladium was measured quantitatively using inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy. Carefully weighed catalysts were dissolved in a 3:1 ratio of concentrated HCl and HNO3, dried, and dissolved again in concentrated HNO3. Yttrium was used as an internal standard and the resultant solutions were analyzed with a Perkin Elmer Optima 3300 XL ICP-OES analyzer. Element standards for each species were used to obtain a quantitative measurement of the catalyst composition. X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS): Measurements using XAS including extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) and X-ray absorption near edge spectroscopy (XANES) were made on the insertion-device beam line of the Materials Research Collaborative Access Team (MRCAT) at the Advanced Photon Source, Argonne National Laboratory. Measurements were made in transmission mode with ionization chambers optimized for the maximum current with linear response (∼1010 photonss−1). A cryogenically cooled double-crystal Si (111) monochromater with resolution (ΔE) better than 2.5eV at 8.979keV (Cu K edge) and 24.350keV (Pd K edge) were used in conjunction with a rhodium-coated mirror to minimize the presence of harmonics [33]. The integration time per data point was 1–3s, and three scans were obtained for each processing condition. Standard procedures based on WINXAS97 software [34] were used to extract the EXAFS data [35]. Phase shifts and backscattering amplitudes were obtained from EXAFS data of the following reference compounds: Pd foil for Pd–Pd, Pd(NH3)4(NO3)2 for Pd–O, CuO and Cu2O for Cu–O, and Cu foil for Cu–Cu. Catalyst samples were pressed into a cylindrical holder with a thickness chosen to give an absorbance (Δμx) of about 1.0 in the Cu or Pd K edge regions. Due to the high density and copper content of the Cu/ZnO based catalysts, fresh catalyst was diluted by a factor of 10 with Al2O3 powder prior to being pressed into a wafer for Cu K edge measurements. For Pd K edge measurements undiluted catalyst was used. The sample holder was centered in a continuous-flow reactor tube 18in. long and 0.75in. diameter to allow transmission of the X-ray beam. The tube was fitted at both ends with polyimide windows with gas valves fitted perpendicular to the tube to allow for reactant gas flow. The reactor setup was placed into a clamshell style electrical furnace, which was controlled and monitored with three type K thermocouples located inside the reactor tube and assembly. The entire reactor and furnace assembly was placed directly into the X-ray beamline with flow of reducing, reactant, and oxidizing gas mixtures introduced at various temperatures, all while being probed by the X-ray beam. While conversion was not explicitly measured during the XAS experiment the catalysts samples were diluted in a 10:1 ratio by mass and the flow rates were high to mimic conditions similar to those observed in the low conversion region in the flow reactor typically of the order of 5%. Under these conditions no temperatures changes were detected upon introduction of the reactants. 2.3 Catalytic activity and selectivity Conversion and products composition were measured at the effluent of a quartz tubular reactor (10.5mm I.D., 30cm long) containing 200mg of sieved catalyst (0.6–1.0mm) supported by quartz wool. Each catalyst was reduced in situ by heating from room temperature at a rate of 5Kmin−1 to 573K and held for 1h under a pure hydrogen flow rate of 50cm3 min−1. Reactant flow rate was 140cm3 min−1 of nitrogen saturated with methanol at 0°C, resulting in a stream containing 3.8% methanol. Oxygen was added to the reactant stream to achieve an O2/CH3OH ratio of 0.5. An overall pressure less than 3.0kPa was carefully maintained inside the reactor to provide constant pressure in the GC sampling system. During kinetic studies the catalyst was diluted and isothermal conditions were maintained in the bed within 1°C. In the activity results presented in Fig. 1 , the temperature reported represents an average bed temperature that serves as relative comparison of the effect of promoters (Pd, ZrO2) on activity. Two gas chromatographs were connected in parallel to analyze reactor effluent. The first (Varian 3300), used a 3.7m HAYESEP Q column for separation and detection of carbon dioxide, methanol, water, and formaldehyde. The second (Varian 920), was equipped with a 1.8m molecular sieve 5A and a 5.0m HAYESEP D connected in series capable to separate nitrogen, oxygen, hydrogen, carbon monoxide, and methane. Product gases were measured in 12-min intervals while the catalyst bed was heated from room temperature to 573K over the course of 3h. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity In our previous work, coprecipitated catalysts promoted with ZrO2 and palladium were found to be more active than a base preparation containing only copper and ZnO [26,27]. Fig. 1a and b depicts methanol conversion, hydrogen and CO selectivity vs. temperature for the catalysts studied in this work. The promoters used have a strong influence on methanol conversion near the light off temperature (LOT), defined here as the temperature at 50% methanol conversion. From Fig. 1a the base preparation, 7Cu/3Zn, has the highest LOT of 194°C, while on the ZrO2 promoted 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr catalyst the LOT is slightly lower at 187°C. The promoted catalysts all reach a similar conversion over 90% at 200°C while the 7Cu/3Zn catalyst approaches complete conversion at 300°C, but the LOT of these catalysts are different depending on the presence of Pd. Catalyst 7Cu/3Zn–Pd has some activity for methanol combustion beginning at ∼110°C, with a LOT of 158°C, 36°C below the 7Cu/3Zn catalyst LOT. The 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd catalyst has the lowest light off temperature, reaching ∼50% conversion and ∼40% hydrogen selectivity at 132°C. The hydrogen and CO selectivity for the coprecipitated catalysts are shown in Fig. 1b. At conversions less than 10%, combustion products dominate. Once the LOT is reached, oxygen conversion reaches 100% and hydrogen selectivity increases roughly 1:1 with conversion up to approximately 200°C. Above the selectivity maximum, both CO and H2O byproducts increase as a result of methanol decomposition and/or the reverse water gas shift reactions. Neither ZrO2 nor palladium promoters significantly affected CO byproduct formation. At 200°C, all four catalysts display less than 3% CO selectivity, which increases linearly with temperature up to ∼18% at 300°C. CO concentrations are low for all the catalysts formulations because the WGS reaction is fast and reach equilibrium in all these conditions. 3.2 Catalyst characterization Total and copper surface areas were determined by BET and N2O decomposition experiments conducted on the catalysts promoted with palladium and zirconium. These structural characteristics including the BET area, mean copper surface area (MSA), copper dispersion, and the CuO crystallite size (from XRD) are presented in Table 2 . Catalyst BET surface area shows a strong dependence on the promoter material. Catalysts without ZrO2, 7Cu/3Zn and 7Cu/3Zn–Pd, have the lowest area, near 20m2 g−1 after calcination. Both catalysts promoted with ZrO2, 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr and 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd, have a higher BET area of 55 and 63m2 g−1, respectively. Addition of 1wt.% palladium may also have a small effect on the BET surface area, with an increase of about 10% observed 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd catalyst. BET areas of catalysts after reduction in H2 at 300°C have a similar trend of area increase when promoted by ZrO2 and palladium as calcined catalysts. A small decrease in surface area upon reduction is observed in both catalysts without ZrO2, from about 20 to 17m2 g−1, while the surface area of catalysts promoted with ZrO2 do not change after reduction. This effect may be explained by increased sintering resistance of copper in catalysts promoted with ZrO2 [11,36]. The surface area and copper dispersion measured for the ZrO2 and palladium promoted catalysts compared to the base Cu/ZnO preparation are also presented in Table 2. On promotion with ZrO2 the copper area increased by a factor of 2, from 9 to 20m2 g−1. Similarly, the mean copper surface area also shows a significant increase, from 14 to 36m2 g−1, resulting in an increase in dispersion from 2.1 to 5.5%. These results are consistent with studies that have shown copper dispersion increasing with addition of ZrO2 in coprecipitated catalysts [11,12,21]. Promoting catalysts with palladium had a slight effect on textural properties such BET, Cu0 surface areas, and dispersion. Both 7Cu/3Zn–Pd and 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd catalysts promoted with palladium have similar BET surface area and Cu dispersion compared to compositions without palladium. Any surface palladium did not influence the N2O reaction with Cu0 when determining copper surface area. These results are likely due to the low palladium loading of 1wt.%, which is distributed throughout the catalyst bulk during synthesis. 3.3 X-ray diffraction XRD patterns of the calcined catalysts are depicted in Fig. 2 as a comparison of 7Cu/3Zn and 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr, with and without 1wt.% Pd. Broad lines corresponding to CuO and ZnO are clearly identifiable in all four patterns, however no peaks could be assigned to either palladium or zirconium compounds in any pattern. The most apparent feature is the significant broadening of CuO and ZnO lines in patterns 2c and 2d of the promoted ZrO2 catalysts. The lack of ZrO2 XRD peaks in patterns in promoted CuO/ZnO catalysts has been attributed to a highly disordered or amorphous state, or small crystallite size, and low wt.% of the ZrO2 phase [11]. CuO particle size, estimated with the Debye–Scherrer equation, is also presented in Table 2 showing that is reduced, from 16–18 to 9–10nm, when promoted with ZrO2. While the estimate of crystallite size by XRD has uncertainties, the trend in reduction in particle CuO size are also supported by multiple measurements of the catalyst surface composition (XPS), the decrease of Cu–Cu coordination number seen in XAS measurements for Pd promoted catalysts, and the BET and N2O decomposition results, correlating with increased copper surface area and Cu dispersion. A small difference in the peak widths and intensity for both CuO and ZnO is also observed for the Pd promoted catalysts (Fig. 2a and b). The estimated CuO particle size in Table 2 is 10% smaller for catalysts promoted by palladium, indicating that the palladium may have an effect on the final CuO and ZnO particle size. However the detected oxide phases were not affected by promotion with palladium. No peaks directly attributable to PdO or palladium compounds could be detected in the fresh calcined catalyst, which is consistent with results obtained by Liu et al. [37] for Pd/ZnO catalysts with low Pd loadings. Fresh reduced catalysts containing both Pd and Cu could not be analyzed via XRD because of the pyrophoric nature of Pd promoted CuO/ZnO catalysts, which results in vigorous oxidation on exposure to air, even when surface copper was passivated via N2O oxidation. 3.4 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy The surface composition of the four coprecipitated catalysts in both calcined and reduced states was measured by XPS. Care was taken with the reduced catalyst samples to avoid contact with atmospheric oxygen while transferring to the XPS sample analysis chamber, but some surface oxidation during transfer cannot be ruled out. Nonetheless, palladium could not be resolved in the doubly promoted catalyst 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd, due to overlap of the binding energy for Pd 3d and Zr 3p peaks. XPS atomic ratios of the four coprecipitated catalysts normalized with respect to Cu0 in both calcined and reduced states are presented in Table 3 . In general, the surface atomic ratios do not correlate well with bulk composition with zinc surface composition being higher indicating surface enrichment by Zn. The palladium and ZrO2 promoted catalysts 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd has the highest Cu/Zn atomic ratio of 1.0:0.9 in the reduced sample, which is still smaller than the nominal 7:3 atomic ratio. Additionally, the ZrO2 promoter surface composition is also enriched compared to the bulk nominal composition in both 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd and 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr in calcined and reduced conditions. Upon reduction, the copper surface ratio increases in all of the catalysts. This effect may be attributed to the loss of oxygen from the CuO lattice, resulting in an increased copper signal from the existing Cu crystallites on the surface of the catalyst. No significant binding energy shifts were detected in the calcined or reduced copper for any of the coprecipitated catalysts, suggesting that palladium and zirconium promoters do not alter the chemical state of the surface of the ex situ freshly calcined or reduced catalyst under UHV conditions. The calcined samples all contain Cu 2p 3/2 peaks centered at approximately 933.8eV with distinct satellite peaks suggesting Cu2+ as in CuO, indicating that the catalyst is in a fully oxidized state [40]. The Cu 2p region was analyzed after ex situ reduction in H2 at 300°C. In this case, the binding energy of 932.5eV for the Cu 2p 3/2 corresponds to metallic Cu0. Satellite peaks were not present in the reduced catalyst, indicating that no Cu2+ remained on the catalyst surface after reduction. Small variations in Zn 2p binding energy were observed in the palladium and ZrO2 promoted catalysts, however no clear trends could be identified. The accepted Zn 2p binding energy for oxidized and reduced zinc are similar, with Zn2+ and Zn0 reported near 1022.0eV [40]. Thus the surface zinc in this work is taken to be mainly ZnO. Palladium was not detected by XPS on the surface of the calcined or reduced 7Cu/3Zn–Pd samples. The most intense Pd 3d peak should form a doublet at 335.2 and 340.5eV [40]. The detection limit of the XPS instrument is of the order of 0.1% atomic, or approximately 10 times less than the bulk concentration of 1%, as measured by ICP-OES. Therefore we conclude that the amount of palladium near the surface of the promoted catalysts is very small, with most of it encapsulated in the catalyst bulk, as a result of the coprecipitation preparation method. 3.5 Temperature programmed reduction TPR profiles for the four coprecipitated catalysts are presented in Fig. 3 . All of the profiles are broad possibly due to multiple overlapping peaks typical of bulk copper catalysts. Profile d represents the 7Cu/3Zn catalyst. The reduction begins slowly at approximately 150°C, with the main hydrogen uptake peak at about 235°C. A large broad shoulder on the high temperature side indicates another reduction peak centered around 262°C. Reduction of 7Cu/3Zn is complete at about 295°C. The relatively high reduction temperature, broad peak, and shoulders agree with the XRD results indicating relatively large crystallites, and with N2O decomposition results suggesting low copper dispersion. Zirconia promoted 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr catalyst is shown as curve c in Fig. 3. This profile has features similar to the Cu/Zn curve, but shifted to lower temperatures. In this case, reduction begins at ∼140°C and peaks at 213°C, about 20°C lower than 7Cu/3Zn. A smaller shoulder and narrower peak compared to the 7Cu/3Zn preparation suggests a narrower Cu crystallite size distribution. Reduction is completed by 250°C. Agrell et al. [11] also found that copper reduction temperature decreases with ZrO2 promotion and that those catalysts resisted sintering after an oxidation/reduction cycle. The sintering resistance is attributed to the ZrO2 phase stabilizing the copper and preventing crystallite growth. Another study concluded that the decrease in CuO reduction temperature in a ZrO2 promoted mixture may be due to interactions at grain boundaries between copper and zirconium [41]. The last two TPR profiles, a and b, in Fig. 3 correspond to palladium promoted 7Cu/3Zn–Pd and 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd catalysts. The profiles are very similar, reduction starts near 130°C, with hydrogen uptake peaks at 179 and 182°C, respectively. In this case the presence of palladium influenced the reduction regardless of CuO particle size, dispersion of copper, and interactions with ZrO2. The lower reduction temperature compared to 7Cu/3Zn and 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr is attributed to a well-known spillover mechanism involving hydrogen adsorption and dissociation on Pd0 crystallites, followed by activated hydrogen migration to CuO [42]. Other studies involving Pd–Cu alloy formation have demonstrated that a palladium–copper system lowers the copper reduction temperature and raises the Pd reduction temperature [43]. The decrease in the reduction temperature of oxides in bimetallic catalysts containing noble metals is well known in the literature and agrees with our TPR results. 3.6 Cu X-ray absorption spectroscopy The oxidation state and alloy formation of copper in the catalysts were studied using the Cu K edge XAS under calcined, reduced, and reaction conditions. In general, The Cu EXAFS results for catalysts with or without palladium promoters demonstrated similar features and fits (coordination number CN, and scattering distance R). Therefore, some data corresponding to 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd and 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr were omitted in Tables 4 and 5 to save space. Both 7Cu/3Zn and 7Cu/3Zn–Pd have distinct XANES and EXAFS features of Cu2+ as in Cu–O at a bond distance of 1.95Å, shown in Table 4, confirming both ex situ XRD and XPS results for copper in calcined catalysts as CuO. All four fresh coprecipitated catalysts reduced in situ in hydrogen at 300°C have spectra similar to what is observed in the reference foil, indicating 100% Cu0. The coordination number, used as a qualitative indicator of particle size, is also listed in Table 4 along with the bond distance R and the Debye–Waller factor (DWF). Copper CN decreased with ZrO2 promotion, and slightly for Pd promoted catalysts, which agrees with the reduction in particle size observed in promoted catalysts from XRD in Table 2. Catalyst 7Cu/3Zn, which has been shown to contain the largest Cu0 crystallites by XRD had a CN of 11.8, approaching that of copper foil, while catalyst 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd has the smallest CN, of 10.1. A coordination number of 0 indicates no observed contribution from the bond distance and type indicated in tables containing EXAFS data. After reduction, the catalysts were exposed to a reaction mixture consisting of 3.8% methanol and 1.9% oxygen at a various temperatures. Fig. 4a and b depicts the Cu XANES region for catalyst 7Cu/3Zn in (a) and 7Cu/3Zn–Pd in (b), collected at room temperature, 150, 200, and 250°C. The other two catalysts 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr and 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd had similar behavior to the catalysts in (a) and (b), respectively, and are not shown. The XANES region was utilized to determine the extent and oxidation state of copper by fitting linear combinations of Cu1+ and Cu0, which exhibit distinctive pre-edge features. No Cu2+ was observed post-reduction or under reaction conditions in either XANES or EXAFS spectra. Beginning with reduced catalysts, all the samples remained as fully reduced Cu0 under reaction conditions at room temperature. As temperature increased to 200°C under reaction conditions, the fresh catalysts oxidize from Cu0 to 100% Cu1+, regardless of promoter materials. Further heating the catalysts to 250°C resulted in a change of the copper oxidation state in palladium promoted catalysts to 80% Cu0 and 20% Cu1+ for catalyst 7Cu/3Zn–Pd and 90% Cu0 for 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd, shown in Table 4. Catalysts not promoted with palladium remained at a Cu1+ oxidation state. The return to the Cu0 oxidation state can be seen in Fig. 4b spectra labeled as 250°C, while Fig. 4a spectra at 250°C exactly overlaps the previous line (not shown). The residual Cu1+ observed in the palladium promoted catalysts at 250°C accounts for 10–20% of the copper in the fresh catalyst preparations 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd and 7Cu/3Zn–Pd shown in Table 4. It is assumed based on the reduction from 100% Cu1+ to Cu0 as temperature increases that the oxidized copper does not dominate the surface of the copper crystallites contained in the catalyst. It is not possible, however, to determine by XAS if Cu1+ is on the surface or the bulk, since XAS it is not a surface sensitive technique. Thus, the Cu1+ may be partially or wholly contained inside larger crystallites, or represent part of the surface where oxygen concentrations are higher. The driving force for the change in oxidation state with temperature might be the change in the concentration of reactants in the reactor as at the high temperature most of the oxygen is consumed. 3.7 Pd X-ray absorption spectroscopy The palladium K edge was probed by XAS for preparations 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd and 7Cu/3Zn–Pd as freshly prepared, and the deactivated D-7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd catalyst identified by a D before its composition. The EXAFS region was fitted to determine the oxidation state of palladium in oxidized, reduced, and reaction conditions. Fig. 5 shows the magnitude of the Fourier transformed (k 2*χ(k)) data vs. the scattering distance R for the Pd reference foil and catalyst 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd after reduction in 4% hydrogen at 300°C, as freshly calcined, and deactivated D-7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd after exposure to air. The reference foil has a Pd–Pd bond distance of 2.76Å, which agrees with the accepted value in palladium metal as expected. The palladium in the reduced catalyst sample has a bond distance of 2.57Å, different than Pd–Pd and Pd–O, and is attributed to a palladium alloy. In addition, the Pd backscattering phase and amplitude are consistent with zinc or copper neighbors, i.e., Pd–Zn or Pd–Cu bonds. There are no peaks at bond distances corresponding to either Pd–O or Pd–Pd phases in the reduced catalyst, indicating that 100% of palladium in the catalyst sample is in an alloy phase. Finally, in the freshly prepared calcined catalysts, palladium existed in an oxidized phase, as PdO, with a characteristic bond distance of 2.03Å and a CN of 4. As Pd could form alloys with Cu and Zn, such alloy is referred hereafter as Pd–M. The coordination number of 9.8 and bond distance of 2.57Å (Table 5) of Pd–M are identical for both 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd and 7Cu/3Zn–Pd catalysts, indicating that the ZrO2 promoter, and the effect on copper and zinc crystallite size seen in XRD experiments does not affect alloy coordination number or bond distance. This result is also consistent with TPR experiments, which showed that ZrO2 has little influence on the reduction temperature, and alloy formation in the catalysts. The FT of k 2 χ EXAFS function of the Pd promoted catalysts under reaction conditions are identical to the reduced 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd shown in Fig. 5. Methanol decomposition or partial oxidation reaction conditions at both 200 and 250°C did not change the Pd–M alloy bond distance, coordination number, or oxidation state compared to the reduced catalyst at room temperature and the Pd EXAFS reduced and reaction states match exactly. For both 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd and 7Cu/3Zn–Pd the Pd–M bond distance remained constant at ∼2.57Å and coordination number near 10 in all conditions is shown in Table 5. The Pd–M alloy state is stable under reaction conditions despite changes in the copper oxidation state for palladium promoted catalysts, which were 100% Cu1+ at 200°C, then changed upon heating to 250°C to approximately 90% Cu0 and 10% Cu1+, suggesting that the oxidation state of copper does not influence the formation and stability of the Pd–M alloy under reaction conditions. Only on exposure to air, in the case of both spent and fresh calcined catalysts shown in Fig. 5, was the palladium alloy not detected in the sample, with palladium existing as PdO. Both Pd–Cu and Pd–Zn alloys are known to form under reducing conditions at moderate temperatures [18,19,37–39,42–45]. For Pd–Zn alloys scattering distances of ∼2.58Å have been observed while Pd–Cu alloys have been reported to have a distance ∼2.62Å. Due to the similarity between scattering of Cu and Zn, an additional experiment was conducted to determine the alloy which alloy could be present. Two series of model impregnated catalysts supported on ZnO and Al2O3 were prepared to study Pd–M alloy formation. These catalyst compositions are listed in Tables 6 and 7 and are labeled Zn-1 to Zn-6 and Al-1 to Al-6 for ZnO and Al2O3 supported samples, respectively. For Al2O3 supported catalysts, palladium loading was set at a constant value while copper and zinc content were adjusted. For ZnO supported catalysts the ZnO is present in large excess with limited copper and palladium. Fig. 6 contains selected Pd K edge EXAFS results as the Fourier transformed (k 2*χ(k)) data vs. R for model catalysts Zn-3, Al-3, Al-5, and the Pd0 reference foil taken at room temperature after reduction in hydrogen. Palladium alloy phases observed for the model catalysts in Fig. 6 are similar to those observed in Fig. 5. The ZnO supported sample Zn-3 has a single peak at a distance of 2.57Å, which is attributed to the Pd–M alloy phase and is distinctly different from the Pd0 foil reference at a distance of 2.75Å. Similarly, Al2O3 supported samples Al-3 and Al-5 also contain alloy phase palladium at 2.55Å. Unalloyed palladium is present in Al2O3 supported samples where palladium exceeds copper loading, indicating that the Al2O3 support may partially inhibit Pd–Zn alloy formation. Tables 6 and 7 also contain the coordination number, scattering distance, and Debye–Waller factor for Pd–M alloy and unalloyed Pd–Pd in the supported model catalysts after reduction in hydrogen. Scattering distances for Pd–M alloys vary from 2.55–2.56Å on Al2O3 to 2.57Å on ZnO supported samples, closely matching Pd–M alloy scattering distances for the coprecipitated catalysts shown in Table 4. No clear trends between copper or zinc content and scattering distance is apparent from the data in the table. Therefore Pd–M alloy composition cannot be determined from the model catalysts using scattering distance alone. A correlation between Cu/Pd molar ratio and alloy coordination number is shown in Fig. 7 for both ZnO and Al2O3 supported model catalysts. A roughly linear relationship between coordination number and Cu:Pd molar ratio is seen for the ZnO supported with Cu>0 in the figure. Alloy formation is discernable from the value of CN even with 0% copper content, which indicates formation of a Pd–Zn alloy. No Pd–Pd bonds corresponding to metallic Pd fit the data in ZnO supported catalysts. However, the nonlinearity between the first two points indicates a difference in the alloy composition when copper is present in the sample. The preference of Pd–Cu alloys over Pd–Zn alloys is also clearly observed on Al2O3 supported catalysts in Fig. 7 where three alloys with constant copper content but variable zinc loading have very similar coordination numbers. The outlier point in the figure for the Al2O3 supported is where metal loading of zinc is a factor of 5 greater than copper. These results indicate that on these model catalysts while both Pd–Zn and Pd–Cu alloys can form at similar reduction temperatures, the Pd–Cu alloy is strongly preferred. The preference is likely due to having both Pd0 and Cu0 present in the catalyst during reduction and reaction, whereas ZnO remains stable at higher temperatures. Palladium and copper metals are miscible and can form a continuous phase at any concentration, while Pd–Zn alloy will not. While the structure of the model catalyst is different than the coprecipitated catalysts it is possible that the similar trends regarding the formation of Pd–M alloys occur. A trimetallic Pd–Zn–Cu phase is also possible and cannot be ruled out. 3.8 Catalyst stability and deactivation Catalyst stability and deactivation were studied by measuring conversion and selectivity during the 100-h time on stream reaction test at constant temperature. The most active 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd catalyst was used for the measurements at conditions which yielded 95% hydrogen selectivity at ∼90% methanol conversion at the start of the stability test. Methanol conversion, hydrogen selectivity, carbon dioxide selectivity, and carbon monoxide concentration were monitored every 4h (more often in the first 10h) until the end of the test. Characterization measurements performed on the deactivated catalyst include XRD, and XAS. Fig. 8 is a plot of the activity and selectivity vs. time on stream at 200°C. The top plot of methanol conversion vs. time shows a steady, gradual decrease in conversion equal to 1.3% per 24h, with a final conversion of 86%, or a total reduction in conversion of approximately 5%. The second plot for hydrogen selectivity depicts a slight decrease from 95% at 0h to 85% at time 100h. The decline in hydrogen selectivity is attributed to the changes of oxidation state of Cu and increase crystallite size during the entire 100-h run with decreasing methanol conversion results in lower hydrogen selectivity in the form of water. Both CO and CO2 selectivity depicted in Fig. 8 showed no change from initial values. The CO2 selectivity remained constant at 97% throughout the entire run, while CO levels remained at 3. Fig. 9 shows an ex situ XRD pattern for the deactivated catalyst. Four distinct phases are easily distinguished from the pattern including Cu0, ZnO, monoclinic ZrO2, and tetragonal ZrO2. Detection of Cu0 in the catalyst correlates well with previous XAS results, which showed that a palladium promoted catalyst easily reduced under reaction conditions. The Cu0 grain size in the deactivated catalyst is significantly larger than the CuO grain size in the fresh catalyst, growing from ∼10 to 40nm, as estimated by the Scherrer equation. In the fresh catalyst ZrO2 phases were not detected by XRD. However, in the deactivated catalyst both monoclinic and tetragonal ZrO2 were detected. Only monoclinic ZrO2 is stable at room temperature, well below the transformation temperature of 1170°C to tetragonal [46], although it is well known that this temperature can be reduced significantly by addition of other oxide compounds [47]. Therefore the undetectable ZrO2 in the fresh catalyst is likely a dispersed or disordered tetragonal phase. With time on stream the tetragonal ZrO2 may sinter and increase the degree of crystallinity, while changing to the stable monoclinic phase at reaction temperature. Both Cu and Pd XAS were measured for the deactivated D-7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd catalyst used in the 100-h stability test, results are shown in Tables 4 and 5. The spent catalyst left untreated post-reaction scanned in air via XAS is estimated to be 90% Cu0 and 10% Cu1+ (Table 4), which agrees with the XRD results indicating bulk Cu0 in Fig. 9. After re-reduction of the deactivated catalysts the copper coordination number remains at approximately 10, near to that of fresh catalyst. The copper oxidation state under reaction conditions changes oxidation state in a similar manner compared to fresh 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd, starting reduced then changing to Cu1+ at intermediate temperatures. However at 250°C under reaction conditions, the deactivated catalyst is less reduced than the fresh catalyst, 65% vs. 90% Cu0. The increase in copper crystallite size may be related to the increase in Cu1+ oxidation state and the deactivation observed in Fig. 8. The Pd EXAFS region of the deactivated catalyst D-7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd after exposure to air is also shown in Fig. 5. The spectra for D-7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd is nearly identical to the freshly calcined 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd preparation with a clear spectra of PdO [44]. The lack of an alloy phase indicates that the Pd–Cu alloy decomposes on exposure to air, even after long times on stream. After the deactivated catalyst was reduced in hydrogen, a Pd–Cu alloy was formed again with a coordination number of 12 (see Table 5), possibly due to alloying with larger copper crystallites. The new alloy bond distances were observed at 2.58Å, very close to the 2.57Å observed in the fresh catalyst. 3.9 Kinetic analysis As noted in Section 1, copper, palladium, and Pd–Zn alloys are known to be active for methanol reforming reactions. Possible candidates for active sites in this work include Cu0, Cu1+, and Pd–Cu alloys which were found to exist under reaction conditions by XAS experiments. Cu2+ has been shown to catalyze the methanol combustion reaction at low conversion in CMR conditions [48,49]. However no Cu2+ was observed in catalysts post-reduction or under reaction conditions, suggesting that there is no contribution from it under the conditions tested. It is expected that Cu1+ is present at lower conversions where oxygen is still present and wherein combustion products CO2 and H2O dominate. The oxidation state changes to Cu0 after the light off temperature is reached, all the oxygen consumed, and the H2 selectivity increases substantially. Several studies have been attributed to Cu0 as active for methanol reforming reactions [48,50,51]. Therefore the active area is likely related, but not proportional to, Cu0 because activity does not scale with copper area as discussed previously. This suggests additional contribution from the Pd–Cu alloys or other active sites formed from complex oxide phase interactions with copper participate as active sites. Activity tests of unalloyed palladium in the absence of both copper and zinc (not shown) confirmed that Pd0 does not catalyze the partial oxidation of methanol to hydrogen, favoring formation of formaldehyde and water at low temperatures, and decomposition with combustion products CO2 and H2O at higher temperatures. Therefore the low surface concentration and alloying behavior of Pd is critical for maintaining selectivity to CO2 and H2 products. The primary role of palladium in the catalyst appears to be to increase the reducibility of the active copper species, which enhances catalytic activity by providing active sites at lower temperatures. To better understand the effects of ZrO2 and palladium promoters on the activity, a kinetic pathway consisting of four overall reactions was fitted to conversion results using for the four coprecipitated catalysts. The partial oxidation of methanol mechanism has been proposed as two step process, combustion followed by steam reforming [18,19]. Steam reforming itself has been shown to involve three overall reactions, including steam reforming, methanol decomposition, and water gas shift [9,10]. Eqs. (1)–(4) are rate expressions used in the pathway for combustion, steam reforming, decomposition, and reverse water gas shift reactions, respectively. The reaction orders for Eq. (1) were obtained using kinetic analysis in a differential reactor in our laboratory assuming that the combustion step is irreversible. The remaining rate equations and reaction orders in Eqs. (2)–(4) were taken from an analysis of steam reforming over a Cu/ZrO2/CeO2 catalyst by Mastalir et al. [52]: (2) r c = k c P Me 1 P O 0.6 (3) r s = k sf P Me 0.6 P W 0.4 − k sr P C O 2 1 P H 2 1 (4) r d = k df P Me 1.3 (5) r w = k wf P H 2 1 P C O 2 1 − k wr P CO 1 P W 1 The above reaction pathway rate expressions, with k i , assumed to have an Arrhenius relationship with temperature were combined with species mass balances in a plug flow reactor. The conversion and selectivities experimentally obtained at various conditions were fitted to the calculated results using a nonlinear least squares analysis routine (MATLAB). Activation energies thus obtained for reactions (2)–(5) are shown in Table 8 as a function of catalyst composition. According to the kinetic parameters in Table 8, addition of ZrO2 to the unpromoted 7Cu/3Zn catalyst resulted in only slight changes to the activation energy of any of the four model reactions. This result is consistent with the observed activity data where ZrO2 promotion alone results in only a slight activity increase. On the other hand, palladium promotion to make the 7Cu/3Zn–Pd catalyst decreases the activation energy of the combustion reaction from 63 to 56kJmol−1 and the steam reforming reaction from 75 to 71kJmol−1, which is attributed to the decrease in copper reduction temperature. The zirconium and palladium promoted catalyst 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd has the lowest activation energies calculated from the reaction pathway. The activity increase is attributed to the increase in copper area from smaller particles and decrease in reduction temperature of the copper by the presence of Pd. The combustion reaction has the greatest decrease in activation energy of 52kJmol−1, which results in the increased activity at lower temperatures. The corresponding higher activity resulted in hydrogen yield below 150°C. Above the light off temperature, both carbon dioxide and hydrogen partial oxidation products dominate with high selectivity above 95% for both hydrogen and carbon dioxide. The activity and selectivity is similar for all four catalysts at temperatures above 200°C. Likewise, the changes in selectivity have very similar trends as the temperature approaches 300°C. The activation energy of methanol decomposition, water gas shift, reverse steam reforming, and reverse water gas shift reactions do not change with catalyst composition. All four catalysts have activation energy near 75kJmol−1 for the reverse water gas shift reaction and 85kJmol−1 for methanol decomposition, and is attributed to similarities in the active area of catalysts at high methanol conversion. The fit of the experimental result to the kinetic model was done at high temperatures and it does not include changes in active sites with reaction conditions observed in the operando experiments. There is little literature information for kinetic constants of the partial oxidation reaction to compare with the parameters obtained. The purpose of the simplified kinetics analysis presented is to show that even through the reaction is rather complex, four reactions suffice to fit the data and explain the major trends observed. 4 Summary and conclusion Palladium and zirconium promoted copper/zinc based coprecipitated catalysts have been evaluated for activity in the partial oxidation of methanol reaction and fully characterized by a variety of techniques. The zirconium promoter has little effect on the activity of the base 7Cu/3Zn catalyst, but changes its structure significantly by decreasing the CuO particle size, increasing the Cu0 active area, and total surface area. On the other hand, the palladium promoter did not significantly influenced the catalyst structure, but had a significant effect on the copper reducibility regardless of CuO particle size. No palladium was detected on the surface of the catalyst via XPS, indicating that less than 0.1at.% palladium exists on the surface. A catalyst promoted with both palladium and zirconium yielded desired structural and reducibility enhancements from the promoters resulting in a synergy that significantly increased activity. The oxidation state of both copper and palladium under reaction conditions was investigated using XANES techniques. Beginning with a reduced catalyst, copper was found to change from Cu0 to Cu1+ under reaction conditions at temperatures approaching 200°C for all coprecipitated catalysts. The copper in both palladium promoted catalysts 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr–Pd and 7Cu/3Zn–Pd then returned to a mostly Cu0 state in catalysts approaching 250°C, while 7Cu/3Zn and 7Cu/3Zn/1Zr remained as Cu1+. The activity enhancement from palladium promotion is attributed to Cu1+ reduction to Cu0 at lower temperatures under reaction conditions. The doubly promoted catalyst also showed good stability over the course of a 100-h test even though the average copper crystallite size increased from approximately 10 to 40nm post-reaction. The increase in copper crystallite size may reduce the amount of active sites available under reaction conditions, from 90% Cu0 in fresh catalyst to 65% in the deactivated catalyst, with the balance observed as Cu1+. The lowered Cu0 content and larger copper crystallites in the catalyst could be responsible for decreased activity while increased Cu1+ may lower catalyst selectivity. Palladium alloy state was determined using EXAFS. Palladium remained in a reduced alloy state regardless of temperature and reaction mixture if copper was maintained as Cu0 and/or Cu1+. However, analysis of a spent catalyst showed that the alloy decomposes to PdO after exposure to air at room temperature. The alloy state of palladium determined by analysis of two additional series of palladium, zinc, and copper supported on Al2O3 and ZnO was determined by XAS experiments. It was found that both Pd–Zn and Pd–Cu can form alloys at reduction temperatures of 300°C or below, however there is a strong preference for the formation of Pd–Cu alloys. Finally, a kinetic pathway involving methanol combustion, steam reforming, decomposition, and reverse water gas shift was used to quantify the effect of the promoters on the activation energy of those reactions in the network. Conversion and selectivity results were fitted to kinetic rate constants. It was found that addition of palladium and ZrO2 significantly decreased the activation energy for both methanol combustion and steam reforming, with a lesser effect on the decomposition and reverse water gas shift reactions. These results agree with the observed activity increase and changes in oxidation state by addition of palladium observed in the catalysts under reaction conditions. At higher temperatures all catalysts have similar oxidation states, which explains the increase in both MD and RWGS reaction rates for all catalysts at temperatures greater than 250°C. coredata.dc:description: Copper and zinc oxide based catalysts prepared by coprecipitation were promoted with palladium and ZrO2, and their activity and selectivity for methanol oxidative reforming was measured and characterized by N2O decomposition, X-ray absorption spectroscopy, BET, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction, and temperature programmed reduction. Addition of ZrO2 increased copper dispersion and surface area, with little effect on activity, while palladium promotion significantly enhanced activity with little change of the catalytic structure. A catalyst promoted with both ZrO2 and palladium yielded hydrogen below 150°C. EXAFS results under reaction conditions showed that the oxidation state of copper was influenced by palladium in the catalyst bulk. A palladium promoted catalyst contained 90% Cu0, while the copper in an unpromoted catalyst was 100% Cu1+ at the same temperature. Palladium preferentially forms an unstable alloy with copper instead of zinc during reduction, which persists during reaction regardless of copper oxidation state. A 100-h time on stream activity measurement showed growth in copper crystallites and change in copper oxidation state resulting in decreasing activity and selectivity. A kinetic model of the reaction pathway showed that palladium and ZrO2 promoters lower the activation energy of methanol combustion and steam reforming reactions.
